About five years ago I moved from Birmingham to NYC, and gave away about 100 boxes of books to thrift stores and friends. The only books I kept were cookbooks, books I hadn't read (and knew I would), and those I wanted to re-read.
It was necessary because my new place was much smaller, but also liberating. Plus, the books went to friends that would read and enjoy them and thrift stores that supported good causes.

Your reviews look great. My only advice would be to update your template so that your recent post links and categories show up in the sidebar. I would also add contact information for publishers (who love to send book bloggers review copies).

I have been blogging (about books and music) for over 11 years, and still enjoy it. Good luck.
Ariel Djanikian's The Office of Mercy is post-apocalyptic and one of the best novels I have read this year.

My absolute favorite bookstores, Brooklyn's WORD and Baltimore's Atomic Books, are geniuses at curating their content to their demographic and having the most knowledgeable and helpful staff members, from the owners on down. I love going into WORD and mentioning a book I liked, then having the bookseller recommend several similar books. Both those stores are active in social media (Twitter, Facebook, Tumblr) and engage there directly with their communities.
One other thing my favorite indies do is host exciting events, these often bring new customers into the store.
Darin Strauss's memoir Half a Life is about this exact subject.
Always funny. If you are in NYC, Dan Wilbur works at Community Bookstore in Brooklyn, stop by and tell him you enjoy the blog (and buy his book).

Literary BFFs at McNally Jackson in Manhattan, the next is in May 9th with Amy Brill Tina Chang
Largehearted Lit at Brooklyn's WORD bookstore, the next is March 26th with Teddy Wayne Michelle Orange
I am also starting a food book series at Housing Works Bookstore in Manhattan in May.
I still cover a ton of books a week on my blog and have a couple of NYC reading series.

My wife and I moved to Brooklyn just over two years ago and plan to live here a long time.
We're in Green-Wood Heights/Windsor Terrace/South Slope (depending on who you talk to), and love it. Neither of us are hipsters, my wife is a physical therapist and I am a writer blogger (okay, maybe I'm a hipster by profession).

My wife and I moved from Birmingham, Alabama to Brooklyn two years ago.
We sold our car six months after moving here, we found we usually used it only to change sides of the street when street sweeping was scheduled.
We love the city, and have adapted very well to the faster-paced lifestyle. The entertainment options are almost infinite, the food is great, and the people have been incredibly welcoming at both work and in our neighborhood (South Slope).
Taxes are much higher than Alabama, as is the cost of living in general.
This is actually not far from me, near 5th ave. 20th St. Great neighborhood.

My wife named our cats Neko and Rilo after the singer-songwriter Neko Case and band Rilo Kiley, respectively. We adopted our dog Lily when she was six months old, and didn't think it was fair to change her name.

I actually post between four and six of these playlists by authors every week. Some talk about the music they listened to while writing their books, others construct soundtracks to film adaptations, and others go on totally different tangents.

John Darnielle is my favorite living singer-songwriter.

Plus, many of his live shows are streamable at the Live Music Archive as well.

"AT the beginning of the summer, I had lunch with my father, the gangster, who was in town for the weekend to transact some of his vague business. We'd just come to the end of a period of silence and ill will--a year I'd spent in love with and in the same apartment as an odd, fagile girl whom he had loathed, on sight, with a frankness and a fury that were not at all like him. But Claire had moved out the month before. Neither my father nor I knew what to do with our new freedom." Michael Chabon in The Mysteries of Pittsburgh
A Confederacy of Dunces by John Kennedy Toole is probably the funniest book I have ever read.

I'd recommend anything by James Ellroy, his characters (even the ones drawn from real life) are unforgettable and he writes some of the best dialogue around.

I tend to give books away instead of loaning them, Often, friends leave my house with a handful of books CDs (I get a ton of both sent my way for review every week).
I only give away what I have already read or don't plan to read (and that my wife doesn't plan to read), that makes it easier for everyone, I'd hate to see a friendship lost over a misplaced book.

I used to feel the same way about CDs, vinyl, and DVDs, but digitized everything and am increasingly streaming content online (through Rdio.com, Netflis, Hulu) instead of even accessing my music movies stored locally.
Having just bought an e-reader myself, I find it a great way to read books (especially comics), and see myself going as digital as possible in the coming year. I thought I would never give up my books, but have been giving everything I have already read away to lighten my load prepare for a move at the end of the year. Something about sharing the books with people who want to read them (instead of hoarding yhem) just feels right.
I am collecting the online "best music of the decade lists," and updating the list daily.
